content.body:
# Lesson 9.4: Building Your Backend - Entities and Repositories

## You've set up your project. Now let's build the data layer!

 +
                THE DATA LAYER (Bottom of the stack):

 +
                1. ENTITIES (Java classes → Database tables)
 +
                   @Entity, @Table, @Id, @Column
 +
                   Example: User class → users table

 +
                2. REPOSITORIES (Database access layer)
 +
                   JpaRepository interface
 +
                   Spring generates SQL automatically!

 +
                WHY START HERE?
 +
                ✓ Foundation for everything else
 +
                ✓ Can test immediately (no UI needed)
 +
                ✓ Database schema auto-created by Hibernate
 +
                ✓ Easy to debug when isolated

 +
                BUILD ORDER:
 +
                1. Create User entity
 +
                2. Create UserRepository
 +
                3. Test with @SpringBootTest
 +
                4. Create Task entity
 +
                5. Create TaskRepository
 +
                6. Test relationships

 +
                Let's build from the ground up!)
            .addAnalogy(Entities and Repositories are Like Blueprint and Builder,
                ENTITY (The blueprint):
 +
                Detailed architectural plan for a house
 +
                Like: User class defines what a user looks like
 +
                Specifies: id, email, password, name, created date

 +
                @Entity annotation = "This is a blueprint for a database table"
 +
                @Id annotation = "This is the house number (unique identifier)"
 +
                @Column = "This is a room in the house"

 +
                REPOSITORY (The builder/contractor):
 +
                The construction crew that builds houses from blueprints
 +
                Like: UserRepository saves/finds users in database

 +
                save() = Build a new house
 +
                findById() = Find house by address
 +
                findAll() = List all houses in neighborhood
 +
                delete() = Demolish a house

 +
                Spring Data JPA = The crew manager
 +
                You just say "build me a house"
 +
                Spring figures out HOW to do it (generates SQL))
            .addTheory(Step 1: Create the User Entity,
                Create: src/main/java/com/yourname/taskmanager/model/User.java

 +
                package com.yourname.taskmanager.model;

 +
                import jakarta.persistence.*;
 +
                import java.time.LocalDateTime;
 +
                import java.util.ArrayList;
 +
                import java.util.List;

 +
                @Entity
 +
                @Table(name = "users")
 +
                public class User {
 +
                    
 +
                    @Id
 +
                    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 +
                    private Long id;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(nullable = false, unique = true, length = 255)
 +
                    private String email;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(nullable = false)
 +
                    private String password;  // Will be hashed!
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(length = 100)
 +
                    private String name;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(name = "created_at", updatable = false)
 +
                    private LocalDateTime createdAt;
 +
                    
 +
                    @OneToMany(mappedBy = "user", cascade = CascadeType.ALL, orphanRemoval = true)
 +
                    private List<Task> tasks = new ArrayList<>();
 +
                    
 +
                    // Default constructor (required by JPA)
 +
                    public User() {
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    // Constructor for creating new users
 +
                    public User(String email, String password, String name) {
 +
                        this.email = email;
 +
                        this.password = password;
 +
                        this.name = name;
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    // Lifecycle callback: set timestamp before insert
 +
                    @PrePersist
 +
                    protected void onCreate() {
 +
                        createdAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    // Getters and Setters
 +
                    public Long getId() { return id; }
 +
                    public void setId(Long id) { this.id = id; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public String getEmail() { return email; }
 +
                    public void setEmail(String email) { this.email = email; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public String getPassword() { return password; }
 +
                    public void setPassword(String password) { this.password = password; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public String getName() { return name; }
 +
                    public void setName(String name) { this.name = name; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public LocalDateTime getCreatedAt() { return createdAt; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public List<Task> getTasks() { return tasks; }
 +
                    public void setTasks(List<Task> tasks) { this.tasks = tasks; }
 +
                })
            .addTheory(Understanding Entity Annotations,
                KEY ANNOTATIONS EXPLAINED:

 +
                @Entity
 +
                - Marks class as JPA entity
 +
                - Hibernate will create database table for this class

 +
                @Table(name = "users")
 +
                - Specifies table name in database
 +
                - Without this, table name = class name ("User")
 +
                - Best practice: explicit table names

 +
                @Id
 +
                - Marks the primary key field
 +
                - Every entity MUST have @Id

 +
                @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 +
                - Database auto-generates ID (1, 2, 3, ...)
 +
                - IDENTITY = uses database auto-increment
 +
                - Other options: SEQUENCE, AUTO, UUID

 +
                @Column(nullable = false, unique = true, length = 255)
 +
                - nullable = false → SQL: NOT NULL
 +
                - unique = true → SQL: UNIQUE constraint
 +
                - length = 255 → SQL: VARCHAR(255)
 +
                - name = "created_at" → column name different from field name

 +
                @OneToMany(mappedBy = "user", cascade = CascadeType.ALL)
 +
                - One user has many tasks (1:N relationship)
 +
                - mappedBy = "user" → Tasks have a 'user' field
 +
                - cascade = ALL → Save/delete user cascades to tasks
 +
                - orphanRemoval = true → Delete task if removed from list

 +
                @PrePersist
 +
                - Lifecycle callback: runs before INSERT
 +
                - Automatically sets createdAt timestamp
 +
                - Other callbacks: @PreUpdate, @PostLoad, etc.)
            .addTheory(Step 2: Create the Task Entity,
                Create: src/main/java/com/yourname/taskmanager/model/Task.java

 +
                package com.yourname.taskmanager.model;

 +
                import jakarta.persistence.*;
 +
                import java.time.LocalDateTime;

 +
                @Entity
 +
                @Table(name = "tasks")
 +
                public class Task {
 +
                    
 +
                    @Id
 +
                    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 +
                    private Long id;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(nullable = false)
 +
                    private String title;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(columnDefinition = "TEXT")
 +
                    private String description;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(nullable = false)
 +
                    private Boolean completed = false;
 +
                    
 +
                    @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
 +
                    @JoinColumn(name = "user_id", nullable = false)
 +
                    private User user;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(name = "created_at", updatable = false)
 +
                    private LocalDateTime createdAt;
 +
                    
 +
                    @Column(name = "updated_at")
 +
                    private LocalDateTime updatedAt;
 +
                    
 +
                    // Constructors
 +
                    public Task() {}
 +
                    
 +
                    public Task(String title, String description, User user) {
 +
                        this.title = title;
 +
                        this.description = description;
 +
                        this.user = user;
 +
                        this.completed = false;
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    // Lifecycle callbacks
 +
                    @PrePersist
 +
                    protected void onCreate() {
 +
                        createdAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 +
                        updatedAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    @PreUpdate
 +
                    protected void onUpdate() {
 +
                        updatedAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    // Getters and Setters
 +
                    public Long getId() { return id; }
 +
                    public void setId(Long id) { this.id = id; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public String getTitle() { return title; }
 +
                    public void setTitle(String title) { this.title = title; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public String getDescription() { return description; }
 +
                    public void setDescription(String description) { 
 +
                        this.description = description; 
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    public Boolean getCompleted() { return completed; }
 +
                    public void setCompleted(Boolean completed) { 
 +
                        this.completed = completed; 
 +
                    }
 +
                    
 +
                    public User getUser() { return user; }
 +
                    public void setUser(User user) { this.user = user; }
 +
                    
 +
                    public LocalDateTime getCreatedAt() { return createdAt; }
 +
                    public LocalDateTime getUpdatedAt() { return updatedAt; }
 +
                })
            .addKeyPoint(Understanding Relationships,
                @ManyToOne (Task side - many tasks to one user):
 +
                @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
 +
                @JoinColumn(name = "user_id", nullable = false)
 +
                private User user;

 +
                - Many tasks belong to one user
 +
                - FetchType.LAZY = Don't load user until accessed
 +
                - JoinColumn = Creates 'user_id' foreign key column
 +
                - nullable = false = Every task MUST have a user

 +
                @OneToMany (User side - one user to many tasks):
 +
                @OneToMany(mappedBy = "user", cascade = CascadeType.ALL)
 +
                private List<Task> tasks = new ArrayList<>();

 +
                - One user has many tasks
 +
                - mappedBy = "user" = Task entity owns the relationship
 +
                - cascade = ALL = Operations cascade (save, delete, etc.)
 +
                - orphanRemoval = true = Delete orphaned tasks

 +
                DATABASE RESULT:
 +
                users table:
 +
                  id | email           | password | name
 +
                  1  | alice@email.com | hashed   | Alice

 +
                tasks table:
 +
                  id | title      | description | completed | user_id
 +
                  1  | Buy milk   | From store  | false     | 1
 +
                  2  | Walk dog   | 30 minutes  | true      | 1

 +
                LAZY vs EAGER Fetching:
 +
                LAZY (recommended):
 +
                - Loads relationship only when accessed
 +
                - Better performance
 +
                - Avoids N1 query problem

 +
                EAGER (use sparingly):
 +
                - Loads relationship immediately
 +
                - Can cause performance issues
 +
                - Use only for small, always-needed data)
            .addTheory(Step 3: Create UserRepository,
                Create: src/main/java/com/yourname/taskmanager/repository/UserRepository.java

 +
                package com.yourname.taskmanager.repository;

 +
                import com.yourname.taskmanager.model.User;
 +
                import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.JpaRepository;
 +

                - IDENTITY = uses database auto-increment

                - Other options: SEQUENCE, AUTO, UUID

                - nullable = false → SQL: NOT NULL

## 🎯 @ManyToOne (Task side - many tasks to one user):
 +
                @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
 +
                @JoinColumn(name = "user_id", nullable = false)
 +
                private User user;

 +
                - Many tasks belong to one user
 +
                - FetchType.LAZY = Don't load user until accessed
 +
                - JoinColumn = Creates 'user_id' foreign key column
 +
                - nullable = false = Every task MUST have a user

 +
                @OneToMany (User side - one user to many tasks):
 +
                @OneToMany(mappedBy = "user", cascade = CascadeType.ALL)
 +
                private List<Task> tasks = new ArrayList<>();

 +
                - One user has many tasks
 +
                - mappedBy = "user" = Task entity owns the relationship
 +
                - cascade = ALL = Operations cascade (save, delete, etc.)
 +
                - orphanRemoval = true = Delete orphaned tasks

 +
                DATABASE RESULT:
 +
                users table:
 +
                  id | email           | password | name
 +

 +
                  id | title      | description | completed | user_id
 +
                  1  | Buy milk   | From store  | false     | 1
 +
                  2  | Walk dog   | 30 minutes  | true      | 1

 +
                LAZY vs EAGER Fetching:
 +
                LAZY (recommended):
 +
                - Loads relationship only when accessed
 +
                - Better performance
 +
                - Avoids N1 query problem

 +
                EAGER (use sparingly):
 +
                - Loads relationship immediately
 +
                - Can cause performance issues
 +
                - Use only for small, always-needed data)

content.body:
# Lesson 9.5: Services and Controllers - The Business Logic

## You have entities and repositories. Now add business logic!\n\n +
                THE LAYERED ARCHITECTURE:\n\n +
                ┌─────────────────────────────┐\n +
                │ CONTROLLER (REST API)       │ ← We'll build this\n +
                │ Handles HTTP requests       │\n +
                │ @RestController             │\n +
                ├─────────────────────────────┤\n +
                │ SERVICE (Business Logic)    │ ← We'll build this\n +
                │ Validation, authorization   │\n +
                │ @Service                    │\n +
                ├─────────────────────────────┤\n +
                │ REPOSITORY (Database)       │ ✓ Already built!\n +
                │ CRUD operations             │\n +
                │ JpaRepository               │\n +
                ├─────────────────────────────┤\n +
                │ DATABASE (PostgreSQL)       │ ✓ Already set up!\n +
                │ Stores data                 │\n +
                └─────────────────────────────┘\n\n +
                PLUS: DTOs (Data Transfer Objects)\n +
                - Never expose entities to clients!\n +
                - DTOs control what data is sent/received\n\n +
                GOAL: Build complete backend API!)
            .addAnalogy(Service and Controller are Like Restaurant Kitchen,
                CONTROLLER (The waiter):\n +
                Takes orders from customers (HTTP requests)\n +
                Like: \"I'd like a cheeseburger, please\"\n +
                Validates: \"Sorry, we don't serve pizza\"\n +
                Returns: Food to customer (HTTP response)\n\n +
                SERVICE (The chef):\n +
                Prepares the food (business logic)\n +
                Like: Checks if ingredients available\n +
                      Follows recipe (business rules)\n +
                      Quality control\n\n +
                REPOSITORY (The pantry/storage):\n +
                Stores and retrieves ingredients\n +
                Like: Get cheese, get buns, store leftovers\n\n +
                DTO (The menu item description):\n +
                Customer sees \"Cheeseburger - $10\"\n +
                NOT: \"Ground beef (cost: $3), bun (cost: $0.50)...\"\n +
                DTOs hide internal details!\n\n +
                WORKFLOW:\n +
                1. Customer orders via waiter (Controller)\n +
                2. Waiter tells chef (Service)\n +
                3. Chef gets ingredients from pantry (Repository)\n +
                4. Chef prepares food (Business logic)\n +
                5. Waiter serves customer (Response))
            .addTheory(Step 1: Create DTOs (Data Transfer Objects),
                WHY DTOs?\n +
                ❌ DON'T return entities from REST API:\n +
                - Exposes database structure\n +
                - May leak sensitive data (passwords!)\n +
                - Tight coupling\n +
                - Circular reference issues (User → Task → User)\n\n +
                ✓ DO use DTOs:\n +
                - Control exactly what data is sent/received\n +
                - Hide sensitive fields\n +
                - Validation annotations\n +
                - Decouple API from database\n\n +
                Create: src/main/java/com/yourname/taskmanager/dto/UserDTO.java\n\n +
                package com.yourname.taskmanager.dto;\n\n +
                import jakarta.validation.constraints.Email;\n +
                import jakarta.validation.constraints.NotBlank;\n +
                import jakarta.validation.constraints.Size;\n +
                import java.time.LocalDateTime;\n\n +
                // Response DTO - What we send to client\n +
                public class UserDTO {\n +
                    private Long id;\n +
                    private String email;\n +
                    private String name;\n +
                    private LocalDateTime createdAt;\n +
                    // No password field! Security!\n +
                    \n +
                    // Constructors\n +
                    public UserDTO() {}\n +
                    \n +
                    public UserDTO(Long id, String email, String name, LocalDateTime createdAt) {\n +
                        this.id = id;\n +
                        this.email = email;\n +
                        this.name = name;\n +
                        this.createdAt = createdAt;\n +
                    }\n +
                    \n +
                    // Getters and Setters\n +
                    public Long getId() { return id; }\n +
                    public void setId(Long id) { this.id = id; }\n +
                    \n +
                    public String getEmail() { return email; }\n +
                    public void setEmail(String email) { this.email = email; }\n +
                    \n +
                    public String getName() { return name; }\n +
                    public void setName(String name) { this.name = name; }\n +
                    \n +
                    public LocalDateTime getCreatedAt() { return createdAt; }\n +
                    public void setCreatedAt(LocalDateTime createdAt) { \n +
                        this.createdAt = createdAt; \n +
                    }\n +
                }\n\n +
                // Request DTO - What we receive from client\n +
                public class CreateUserRequest {\n +
                    \n +
                    @NotBlank(message = \"Email is required\")\n +
                    @Email(message = \"Email must be valid\")\n +
                    private String email;\n +
                    \n +
                    @NotBlank(message = \"Password is required\")\n +
                    @Size(min = 8, message = \"Password must be at least 8 characters\")\n +
                    private String password;\n +

# Lesson 9.6: Authentication - Securing Your API

## Right now, ANYONE can access your API!\n\n +
                CURRENT PROBLEM:\n +
                GET /api/tasks → Returns ALL tasks\n +
                DELETE /api/tasks/123 → Deletes ANYONE's task\n +
                No login required!\n\n +
                AUTHENTICATION = Who are you?\n +
                AUTHORIZATION = What can you do?\n\n +
                SPRING SECURITY 6 provides:\n +
                ✓ User registration and login\n +
                ✓ Password hashing (BCrypt)\n +
                ✓ Session management\n +
                ✓ Protection against common attacks\n +
                ✓ JWT token support (stateless auth)\n\n +
                TWO APPROACHES:\n +
                1. SESSION-BASED (Simpler, for beginners)\n +
                   - Login creates session\n +
                   - Session stored on server\n +
                   - Good for traditional web apps\n\n +
                2. TOKEN-BASED (JWT)\n +
                   - Login returns JWT token\n +
                   - Client sends token with each request\n +
                   - Stateless, good for APIs\n\n +
                LEARNING PATH:\n +
                This lesson: HTTP Basic Auth (simple, for testing)\n +
                Later lessons: JWT tokens (production-ready)\n\n +
                NOTE: Basic Auth is NOT recommended for production.\n +
                We use it here to understand Spring Security fundamentals.\n +
                You'll learn JWT (the production standard) in upcoming lessons!)
            .addAnalogy(Authentication is Like Airport Security,
                WITHOUT AUTHENTICATION (Current state):\n +
                Anyone walks onto any airplane\n +
                Like: Anyone can access /api/tasks\n\n +
                WITH AUTHENTICATION:\n\n +
                1. REGISTRATION (Create account):\n +
                   Get a passport (one time)\n +
                   Like: POST /api/auth/register\n +
                   Stores: email, hashed password, name\n\n +
                2. LOGIN (Authenticate):\n +
                   Show passport at security\n +
                   Like: POST /api/auth/login\n +
                   Receives: Boarding pass (session/JWT)\n\n +
                3. ACCESS PROTECTED RESOURCE:\n +
                   Show boarding pass to board plane\n +
                   Like: Send session cookie/JWT with request\n +
                   Server checks: Is boarding pass valid?\n\n +
                4. LOGOUT:\n +
                   Destroy boarding pass\n +
                   Like: POST /api/auth/logout\n +
                   Session invalidated\n\n +
                SECURITY CHECKPOINT = Spring Security Filter\n +
                Checks every request before allowing access)
            .addTheory(Step 1: Add Spring Security Dependency,
                Add to pom.xml:\n\n +
                <dependency>\n +
                    <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>\n +
                    <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-security</artifactId>\n +
                </dependency>\n\n +
                <!-- For JWT (optional, advanced) -->\n +
                <dependency>\n +
                    <groupId>io.jsonwebtoken</groupId>\n +
                    <artifactId>jjwt-api</artifactId>\n +
                    <version>0.12.5</version>\n +
                </dependency>\n +
                <dependency>\n +
                    <groupId>io.jsonwebtoken</groupId>\n +
                    <artifactId>jjwt-impl</artifactId>\n +
                    <version>0.12.5</version>\n +
                    <scope>runtime</scope>\n +
                </dependency>\n +
                <dependency>\n +
                    <groupId>io.jsonwebtoken</groupId>\n +
                    <artifactId>jjwt-jackson</artifactId>\n +
                    <version>0.12.5</version>\n +
                    <scope>runtime</scope>\n +
                </dependency>\n\n +
                RESTART APPLICATION:\n +
                ./mvnw spring-boot:run\n\n +
                WHAT CHANGED?\n +
                - All endpoints now require authentication!\n +
                - GET http://localhost:8080/api/tasks → 401 Unauthorized\n +
                - Default user: \"user\"\n +
                - Password: Printed in console logs\n +
                  \"Using generated security password: abc123-def456-...\"\n\n +
                Test with curl:\n +

content.body:
# Lesson 9.9: Deployment - From Local to Production

## Your app works locally. Now make it accessible to the world!

 +
                DEPLOYMENT JOURNEY:

 +
                1. LOCAL DEVELOPMENT:
 +
                   - ./mvnw spring-boot:run
 +
                   - Only you can access it
 +
                   - Database on localhost

 +
                2. CONTAINERIZATION (Docker):
 +
                   - Package app  database together
 +
                   - Runs the same everywhere
 +
                   - Easy to deploy

 +
                3. PRODUCTION ENVIRONMENT:
 +
                   - Cloud server (AWS, Azure, Heroku)
 +
                   - Real domain (taskmanager.com)
 +
                   - HTTPS encryption
 +
                   - Always available (99.9% uptime)

 +
                GOAL: Deploy your task manager so others can use it!)
            .addAnalogy(Deployment is Like Publishing a Book,
                WRITING (Development):
 +
                Draft on your computer
 +
                Only you can read it
 +
                Like: Running on localhost:8080

 +
                PRINTING (Building Docker image):
 +
                Convert manuscript to printed books
 +
                Same content, portable format
 +
                Like: docker build creates image

 +
                BOOKSTORE (Cloud server):
 +
                Place books on shelves
 +
                Anyone can buy them
 +
                Like: Deploy to AWS/Heroku

 +
                ISBN (Domain name):
 +
                taskmanager.com instead of localhost:8080
 +
                Like: Custom domain

 +
                DISTRIBUTION (CI/CD):
 +
                Automatic printing when you update draft
 +
                Like: Auto-deploy on git push)
            .addTheory(Step 1: Create Production-Ready Dockerfile,
                Create: Dockerfile (in project root)

 +
                # Multi-stage build for smaller image (2024-2025 best practice)
 +
                FROM eclipse-temurin:21-jdk-alpine AS builder
 +
                WORKDIR /app
 +
                
 +
                # Copy Maven wrapper and pom.xml first (for layer caching)
 +
                COPY .mvn/ .mvn/
 +
                COPY mvnw pom.xml ./
 +
                
 +
                # Download dependencies (cached if pom.xml unchanged)
 +
                RUN ./mvnw dependency:go-offline
 +
                
 +
                # Copy source code
 +
                COPY src ./src
 +
                
 +
                # Build application
 +
                RUN ./mvnw clean package -DskipTests
 +
                
 +
                # Production stage - smaller image
 +
                FROM eclipse-temurin:21-jre-alpine
 +
                WORKDIR /app
 +
                
 +
                # Create non-root user for security
 +
                RUN addgroup -S spring && adduser -S spring -G spring
 +
                USER spring:spring
 +
                
 +
                # Copy JAR from builder
 +
                COPY --from=builder /app/target/*.jar app.jar
 +
                
 +
                # Expose port
 +
                EXPOSE 8080
 +
                
 +
                # Health check
 +
                HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=3s --start-period=40s \
 +
                  CMD wget --no-verbose --tries=1 --spider http://localhost:8080/actuator/health || exit 1
 +
                
 +
                # Run application
 +
                ENTRYPOINT ["java", "-jar", "app.jar"]

 +
                KEY FEATURES:
 +
                ✓ Multi-stage build (smaller final image)
 +
                ✓ Layer caching (faster builds)
 +
                ✓ Non-root user (security)
 +
                ✓ Health check (monitoring)
 +
                ✓ Alpine Linux (lightweight))
            .addTheory(Step 2: Create Docker Compose Configuration,
                Create: docker-compose.yml

 +
                version: '3.8'

 +
                services:
 +
                  # PostgreSQL Database
 +
                  db:
 +
                    image: postgres:15-alpine
 +
                    container_name: taskmanager-db
 +
                    environment:
 +
                      POSTGRES_DB: taskmanager
 +
                      POSTGRES_USER: ${DB_USER:-taskuser}
 +
                      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: ${DB_PASSWORD:?Database password required}
 +
                    volumes:
 +
                      - postgres-data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
 +
                    ports:
 +
                      - "5432:5432"
 +
                    healthcheck:
 +
                      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U taskuser"]
 +
                      interval: 10s
 +
                      timeout: 5s
 +
                      retries: 5
 +
                    networks:
 +
                      - taskmanager-network
 +
                
 +
                  # Spring Boot Application
 +
                  app:
 +
                    build:
 +
                      context: .
 +
                      dockerfile: Dockerfile
 +
                    container_name: taskmanager-app
 +
                    environment:
 +
                      SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE: prod
 +
                      SPRING_DATASOURCE_URL: jdbc:postgresql://db:5432/taskmanager
 +
                      SPRING_DATASOURCE_USERNAME: ${DB_USER:-taskuser}
 +
                      SPRING_DATASOURCE_PASSWORD: ${DB_PASSWORD:?Database password required}
 +
                      SPRING_JPA_HIBERNATE_DDL_AUTO: validate
 +
                      SERVER_PORT: 8080
 +
                    ports:
 +
                      - "8080:8080"
 +
                    depends_on:
 +
                      db:
 +
                        condition: service_healthy
 +
                    restart: unless-stopped
 +
                    networks:
 +
                      - taskmanager-network
 +
                
 +
                volumes:
 +
                  postgres-data:
 +
                
 +
                networks:
 +
                  taskmanager-network:
 +
                    driver: bridge

 +
                KEY FEATURES:
 +
                ✓ Environment variables (secure secrets)
 +
                ✓ Health checks (wait for database)
 +
                ✓ Named volumes (persistent data)
 +
                ✓ Custom network (container communication)
 +
                ✓ Restart policy (automatic recovery))
            .addKeyPoint(Step 3: Environment Variables for Production,
                Create: .env (NEVER commit this file!)

 +
                # Database Configuration
 +
                DB_USER=taskuser
 +
                DB_PASSWORD=super-secure-password-change-this

 +
                # Application Configuration
 +
                SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod

 +
                Add to .gitignore:
 +
                .env
 +
                *.env

 +
                Create: .env.example (commit this one)

 +
                # Database Configuration
 +
                DB_USER=taskuser
 +
                DB_PASSWORD=your-secure-password-here

 +
                # Application Configuration
 +
                SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod

 +
                WHY?
 +
                ✓ .env contains real secrets (never in Git)
 +
                ✓ .env.example shows what variables are needed
 +
                ✓ Team members copy .env.example to .env
 +
                ✓ Each environment has different .env file

 +
                PRODUCTION SECRETS:
 +
                On AWS/Azure/Heroku:
 +
                - Set environment variables in dashboard
 +
                - Never hardcode in docker-compose.yml
 +
                - Use secrets management (AWS Secrets Manager, etc.))
            .addTheory(Step 4: Deploy with Docker Compose,
                BUILD AND RUN:

 +
                # Build the Docker image
 +
                docker compose build

 +
                # Start all services (app  database)
 +
                docker compose up -d

 +
                # View logs
 +
                docker compose logs -f app

 +
                # Check status
 +
                docker compose ps

 +
                Expected output:
 +
                NAME                  IMAGE              STATUS
 +
                taskmanager-db        postgres:15-alpine  Up (healthy)
 +
                taskmanager-app       taskmanager_app     Up

 +
                ACCESS APPLICATION:
 +
                http://localhost:8080

 +
                VERIFY HEALTH:
 +
                curl http://localhost:8080/actuator/health
 +
                {
 +
                  "status": "UP",
 +
                  "components": {
 +
                    "db": {"status": "UP"},
 +
                    "diskSpace": {"status": "UP"}
 +
                  }
 +
                }

 +
                USEFUL COMMANDS:
 +
                docker compose down          # Stop all services
 +
                docker compose down -v       # Stop and delete volumes
 +
                docker compose restart app   # Restart app only
 +
                docker compose exec app sh   # Shell into container
 +
                docker compose logs db       # Database logs)
            .addTheory(Step 5: Cloud Deployment Options (2024-2025),
                OPTION 1: HEROKU (Easiest, Free Tier)

 +
                1. Install Heroku CLI:
 +
                   curl https://cli-assets.heroku.com/install.sh | sh

 +
                2. Login:
 +
                   heroku login

 +
                3. Create app:
 +
                   heroku create taskmanager-yourname

 +
                4. Add PostgreSQL:
 +
                   heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql:mini

 +
                5. Set environment variables:
 +
                   heroku config:set SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod

 +
                6. Deploy:
 +
                   git push heroku main

 +
                7. Open app:
 +
                   heroku open

 +
                URL: https://taskmanager-yourname.herokuapp.com

 +
                OPTION 2: AWS (Professional, Scalable)

 +
                Using AWS Elastic Beanstalk:
 +
                1. Package app: ./mvnw package
 +
                2. Create Elastic Beanstalk application
 +
                3. Upload JAR file
 +
                4. Add RDS PostgreSQL database
 +
                5. Configure environment variables

 +
                OPTION 3: DIGITAL OCEAN (Simple, Affordable)

 +
                Using App Platform:
 +
                1. Connect GitHub repository
 +
                2. Configure build command: ./mvnw package
 +
                3. Add managed PostgreSQL database
 +
                4. Auto-deploys on git push

 +
                OPTION 4: RAILWAY.APP (Modern, Developer-Friendly)

 +
                1. Connect GitHub repo
 +
                2. Add PostgreSQL service
 +
                3. Auto-detects Spring Boot
 +
                4. Deploys automatically

 +
                COST COMPARISON (2024-2025):
 +
                Heroku: Free tier (limited hours) → $7/month
 +
                Railway: $5/month credit → $20/month
 +
                DigitalOcean: $5/month → $12/month
 +
                AWS: Pay-as-you-go (can be free tier eligible))
            .addTheory(Step 6: Production Checklist,
                BEFORE DEPLOYING TO PRODUCTION:

 +
                SECURITY:
 +
                ☐ All passwords use BCrypt hashing
 +
                ☐ No secrets in Git repository
 +
                ☐ HTTPS enabled (not HTTP)
 +
                ☐ CORS configured for specific domain
 +
                ☐ SQL injection protection (JPA handles this)
 +
                ☐ XSS protection (frontend escapes HTML)
 +
                ☐ Rate limiting on login endpoint

 +
                DATABASE:
 +
                ☐ ddl-auto set to 'validate' (NOT create-drop)
 +
                ☐ Database backups configured
 +
                ☐ Connection pool configured
 +
                ☐ Indexes on frequently queried columns

 +
                MONITORING:
 +
                ☐ Spring Boot Actuator enabled
 +
                ☐ Health check endpoint working
 +
                ☐ Logging configured (not just console)
 +
                ☐ Error tracking (Sentry, Rollbar)
 +
                ☐ Uptime monitoring (UptimeRobot, Pingdom)

 +
                PERFORMANCE:
 +
                ☐ Database queries optimized (no N1)
 +
                ☐ Static files cached
 +
                ☐ Gzip compression enabled
 +
                ☐ Connection timeouts configured

 +
                TESTING:
 +
                ☐ All tests passing (./mvnw test)
 +
                ☐ Manual testing in production-like environment
 +
                ☐ Load testing (optional but recommended)

 +
                DOCUMENTATION:
 +
                ☐ README with setup instructions
 +
                ☐ API documentation (optional)
 +
                ☐ Environment variables documented)
            .addExample(Step 7: CI/CD with GitHub Actions,
                Automate deployment on every push to main:

 +
                Create: .github/workflows/deploy.yml

 +
                name: Deploy to Production

 +
                on:
 +
                  push:
 +
                    branches: [ main ]

 +
                jobs:
 +
                  test:
 +
                    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 +
                    steps:
 +
                      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
 +
                      
 +
                      - name: Set up JDK 21
 +
                        uses: actions/setup-java@v4
 +
                        with:
 +
                          java-version: '21'
 +
                          distribution: 'temurin'
 +
                      
 +
                      - name: Run tests
 +
                        run: ./mvnw test
 +
                
 +
                  deploy:
 +
                    needs: test
 +
                    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 +
                    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
 +
                    steps:
 +
                      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
 +
                      
 +
                      - name: Deploy to Heroku
 +
                        uses: akhileshns/heroku-deploy@v3.13.15
 +
                        with:
 +
                          heroku_api_key: ${{ secrets.HEROKU_API_KEY }}
 +
                          heroku_app_name: "taskmanager-yourname"
 +
                          heroku_email: "your.email@example.com"

 +
                WORKFLOW:
 +
                1. Push code to GitHub
 +
                2. GitHub Actions runs tests
 +
                3. If tests pass, deploys to Heroku
 +
                4. Users see new version automatically

 +
                ADD HEROKU API KEY:
 +
                1. Get key: heroku auth:token
 +
                2. GitHub → Settings → Secrets → New secret
 +
                3. Name: HEROKU_API_KEY
 +
                4. Value: paste token)
            .addWarning(Common Deployment Mistakes,
                ❌ MISTAKE 1: Using development profile in production
 +
                ddl-auto: create-drop (deletes all data on restart!)
 +
                FIX: SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod, ddl-auto: validate

 +
                ❌ MISTAKE 2: Hardcoding database URL
 +
                url: jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/db
 +
                FIX: Use environment variables

 +
                ❌ MISTAKE 3: No health checks
 +
                Container appears running but app is crashed
 +
                FIX: Add HEALTHCHECK in Dockerfile

 +
                ❌ MISTAKE 4: Root user in container
 +
                Security vulnerability
 +
                FIX: Create non-root user in Dockerfile

 +
                ❌ MISTAKE 5: Exposing sensitive endpoints
 +
                /actuator/env shows all environment variables!
 +
                FIX: Restrict actuator endpoints in production

 +
